Articles.Content: At the end of the day, 1.0 will ship based on their internally decided deadline, we get some new toys to play with, and any cut features move to 1.1. Great devnotes, the team is working hard - I'm not worried.

For the past 3 1/2 years *at least*, Squad has moved deadlines all over the place! For very good reasons, and with very good results! Why the change now? 

You have years of experience under your belt, telling you not to release a feature before it's ready, telling you it's okay to go back to work and release it later. Remember the first version of the contracts? Remember going to experimentals, finding the contracts weren't ready, and choosing to go back to work on them some more? That was a good idea!

It's so mystifying. *Everybody* who cares about KSP and has been paying even slight attention knows that this is not the way to officially release a game. All of Squad's previous words and actions illustrate that you know this better than anybody. It looks exactly like control of the whole project has fallen into the hands of some new party clueless about game development; somebody who doesn't care about the game's commercial success. If that's not what changed... what did?

> 
> I view career as so much more than "unlocking stuff". It's about accomplishing what you can with the tools and funding you have available, then being rewarded for your successes. Once the tech tree is fully researched, the game doesn't end: you still have your reputation and funds to balance and you still have plenty to do from that point onwards. You can go ahead with contracts to fund your own agenda.

I agree that's how it should be, (tech tree just the start), but I also agree with tater:

> 
> The point of a campaign or career game is to provide some sort of context, and be immersive, IMO. That I have to actively alter the way I view contracts is in fact anti-immersive. I have to assume any pure science contracts are not "contracts," but ideas from my own scientists, for example. 
> Like it or not, unlocking tech is the only reward system. We can all play for our own reasons, but there is some psychology at play

The problem I have with cthe tech tree is it presents a more clear, tangible goal than anything else. That and the way each biome can basically be ticked of makes the game seem less about having your own space program, and more about going planet hoping until everything is ticked off. 

There are contracts, but having them as the main reason to keep going to other planets, and to set up bases and things takes the initiative out of the players hands. It's like someone else is calling the shots, and the player just executing them.

Tw1, what if contracts and what are now the "explore" contracts were very explicitly different things. The latter would be renamed "Missions" and they come from your own program scientists. Most of the science contracts (survey/sample collection/eva/science from orbit, etc) would then be from your own team of science guys. They are not telling you what to do, you have a meeting, and they throw ideas out and you pick. If you reject them, they go back to their cubicles and brainstorm some more.

Ideally they would be more like the "explore" contracts, and would be less random feeling, and more sensible. You'd need to survey, or take a ridiculously low alt photo of some part of the Mun, for example, and that would cause a new explore contract to be generated to land---within XXkm of where that last mission was accomplished. Have a pattern of doing science that makes sense. Orbital science (mapping, really), hi-res images of landing sites (visual survey at ridiculous altitudes (so maybe a crasher type probe)). Completion then unlocks the landing missions, but generated procedurally using the coords of the hi-res mission(s). Those contain the EVA, sample collection, and other science, perhaps as they are now, scattered nearby (with that point as the center, and all within some range).

With scanning in, "biome" specific science might not be available until you first ID the biome's existence via mapping, etc. That creates some immersion, IMHO.

> 
> **The release animations are a waste of time!** please redirect that art and animation talent to producing and refining IN-GAME CONTENT.

The release animations aren't made for us, they're there to showcase the game to those who may be interested in buying it. They help showcase the fact that KSP is making progress out of Early Access into a full game.

Look at the KSP Store page on Steam. Games on Steam typically have a few videos that show off the game. I've often bought indie and Early Access games based on a combination of the video and the feedback given by other players. The videos on the Store page currently consist of two release animations (First Contract and Economic Boom) and a video where MaxMaps explains the Asteroid Redirect Mission pack. There's nothing for 0.90.

When I've been trying to get other people I know interested in KSP, I've often linked the release animations to my friends via social media to encourage them to give KSP a try. We need a video for 1.0 that can sit on the Store page, and YouTube, and on social media, that explains what KSP is and why both Joe Average and hardcore space enthusiasts alike should want to get their hands on this game.

> 
> It is really great to see you guys sharing all this information with us. It enhances the sense of community that KSP has created for us all. 
>  I have noticed that you guys have increased the amount of contact with us recently and that's really exciting as I can feel the end coming. 
> 
>  Or rather, the beginning. ![:wink:](//kerbal-forum-uploads.s3.us-west-2.amazonaws.com/emoticons/default_k_wink.gif)
> 
> Thank you also for all your hard work. I look forward to hearing about your plans for the 1.0 release.

This is not the end, it is not even the beginning of the end, it is perhaps the end of the beginning.

All of these this will be mandatory for me, so you don't have to give me a pre-release version\*.

\*Hinting to using this valuable data for the QA\*

Anyway SQUAD, keep up the great work with updates, and possibly recreate the Magic Boulder (or unknown Easter Egg soon).

The trouble is that most all tech should be in the first few nodes. Ladders, PV panel, many engines/tanks. Using RL as a rough benchmark, probe cores even predate capsules (vostok and mercury flew men in 1961, and tests earlier). That puts even NERVA in at the same time as the mk1 capsule. The US launched an RTG the same year as Mercury flights (1961). The vast bulk of the KSP tech tree is crammed in a short time period.

They spread the science parts for "gameplay" which is odd given the actual parts (thermometer is not around, but they can build rockets?). It;s a good reward system, but it makes no sense whatsoever.

well then shame on me for being the odd one out, but scripted pre-rendered animations mean diddly squat to me. I say take that effort and channel it in to in-game visuals and make a video with that. Nassault's videos are made from modded in-game footage, they look stunning. why not spend time making the stock game visuals look that good and make release videos with that? two birds, one work flow.

What are these "release animations" you speak of. It's not something I'd ever watch. If one comes on, I reflexively hit spacebar and hope it goes away. If not, I might leave and get a drink while it loads.

We're not talking about any kind of ingame title screen video. We're talking about the videos that are the very first thing anybody sees when considering whether to buy on Steam. For that reason, the videos are kind of important. Just a bit.

> The trouble is that most all tech should be in the first few nodes. Ladders, PV panel, many engines/tanks. Using RL as a rough benchmark, probe cores even predate capsules (vostok and mercury flew men in 1961, and tests earlier). That puts even NERVA in at the same time as the mk1 capsule. The US launched an RTG the same year as Mercury flights (1961). The vast bulk of the KSP tech tree is crammed in a short time period.
> They spread the science parts for "gameplay" which is odd given the actual parts (thermometer is not around, but they can build rockets?). It;s a good reward system, but it makes no sense whatsoever.

We had manned craft technology a long time before anyone came near space. The B-29 had a pressurized cockpit in WWII. You could argue that the A-4/V-2 was unmanned, and it was, but it had very primitive guidance with almost no capability to run programs.

Plus, the first satellites launched had technology very inferior to the probe cores in game.

And you can earn all the science in a small time period.

I say make rockets launchable without needing a capsule at all. Using cables and such from the ground, so we can then have A4/V-2 like rockets. Then have some very simple guidance mechanism, that says 'Go in direction 'x' at time 'y'." This would be available at around the same time as simple aircraft. For research I still say an X-COM style would be ideal. You can timewarp in that game, too. Also, Kerbal salaries, with staff at each building. Eh... Maybe not salaries. But it is supposed to be a tycoon (business "simulator", right?) game.
You're preaching to the choir, brotha'. ![:)](//kerbal-forum-uploads.s3.us-west-2.amazonaws.com/emoticons/default_k_smiley.gif)

> 
> well then shame on me for being the odd one out, but scripted pre-rendered animations mean diddly squat to me.

You've heard of parallel development, yes? It's where multiple people with differing skill sets work on differing aspects. This is a good thing.

Bleating about fixing in-game asset quality is pointless when there is a maximum ceiling of ~3.5GB of ram before Unity 32bit will crash. It has no method to cope memory access violations and will terminate. Lots of corrected and gorgeous graphics would be great. Apart from the engine not coping with the "load everything always" model of texture management and crapping itself.

As it is, that ceiling is so close the developer is considering the stock use DDS texture formatting to actually cope with the (increased yet again) ridiculous numbers and amount of in-game of textures. This means 1.0 is likely to have a considerable footprint increase.

Yes I'd like to see some better textures. So would most people. However such finesse usually occurs towards the end of the build cycle once the actual mechanics and frameworks are stable; right now core functionality is broken in some not-great ways; and the animation and graphics guys can't really do much about that, hey.

Dan working on in-game assets is happening anyway. I believe he's involved with work on the female kerbal? So your constant requests for people to do your bidding is actually occurring. Just perhaps not on the things you personally "give a crap" about.

By the way those things that mean "diddly squat" to you? - they help increase the source material available for prospective new players who are pondering the game. More people entering the community means more funding which means more likelihood that Squad will bother to continue development - for example do that texture work you want to have happen.

So that? That's important for the longevity of KSP.

> Tw1, what if contracts and what are now the "explore" contracts were very explicitly different things. The latter would be renamed "Missions" and they come from your own program scientists. Most of the science contracts (survey/sample collection/eva/science from orbit, etc) would then be from your own team of science guys. They are not telling you what to do, you have a meeting, and they throw ideas out and you pick. If you reject them, they go back to their cubicles and brainstorm some more.

Apart from the name change, and the change that the source given would be with your organisation, I'm not sure how something like this would be significantly different to the current contracts.

It doesn't quite cover two of the main downsides to contracts\*- they aren't always readily available, and it still has the player sort of being told exactly where to go by something else. 

I'd like to see something like science hotspots that you can find by yourself once you have the technology. Orbital scans might reveal the course location, you'd find the detailed locations on the ground. Some could be set and permanent, others might appear and disappear with time. Your scientists might give pointers to help you in the right direction, E.G travel in the direction that makes [sensor readings A & B] increase, but it's up to you to actually find them, putting you in the role of planet investigator. 

I don't see anything wrong with the existing science/server contracts, my personal fanon is that the KSP spearheads a group of space interested organisations, but having them be the only reason to keep going to planets seems a shame.

Being offered money to land on a planet does seem a little strange, but it is one way to get funding. I'd like to see them sync with launch windows (if they don't already).

Though what I've wanted to see for a while now is something that measures your progress based on ongoing levels of success. Some sort of metric that measures things like how much your space program is contributing to science, how cost effective your missions are, how well your kerbals are treated, etc, but that would need a few more key features, and might have to wait for future expansions.

I am quite looking forward to the trailer. I'm hopeing it will feature Valentina a fair bit, at the moment there's practically nothing to inform fanwork writers about her character.

Well, I'd have the Missions pay up front as a budget.

The game has a finite number of "biomes" (no bio even possible in most, bad name), and a couple altitudes. So there are samples/eva/experiments for each biome and a couple altitudes. The game already tells you what to do. Go to n of N of those possibilities, and do all science actions. That's it, you are entirely constrained.

I think of it this way, you tell Linus and Werner (the science guy at the dumb "strategies" office, plus Werner for what is possible), "what can we do now that we've reached orbit?

Linus goes back, hashes stuff out with his people and maybe Werner figures out what the next spaceflight tests need to be done. The Mission Planning office (mission control is entirely misused as a name in KSP, that's for in-flight missions) would then show Missions (with your own KSC flag) they have come up with. Again, there are finite possible missions by definition. They are not "telling you what to do" any more than the director of NASA is "told what to do" by the people who actually know what they are talking about science-wise. 

Werner might result in "Expand Orbital Spaceflight techniques" appearing which would be a multipart mission like "Explore the Mun," only with "rendezvous and dock with another spacecraft" or satisfy an orbit (like a sat contract), then a new one appears that is similar, with a plane change. Linus would come back with "Explore the Mun" which would be more science (vs landing) and would include orbital science, and other missions preparatory to landing. It might include a bunch of visual survey type things widely scattered (to represent mapping). Upon completion, this unlocks "Land kerbals on the Mun" "Munar science" etc. They have more specific criteria. One might be landing anywhere, or it might require landing in some area that has had detailed science done in the previous mission(s). If your planetary geologist says that the following 6 places are the most interesting to land, are you "doing what you are told" if that is where you send you mission? lol!!! I almost spat beer all over my new laptop when I read that!![:D](//kerbal-forum-uploads.s3.us-west-2.amazonaws.com/emoticons/default_k_cheesy.gif)

 Clearly you're missing the point of the concept of tech progression in general (which is to deny players access to specific parts until they've acquired an arbitrary number of "points" to unlock that part) and tech trees specifically (which is to create research branches that funnels player focus in a specific direction). Squad's rationalization for having a tech tree to begin with was originally to make the game more accessible to new players:

> 
> The big thing with R&D isn't to impose a grind where parts are unlocked as a reward for something. What I want to get out of it is a mechanic through which the game presents itself gradually to players, to not welcome you with an overwhelming wall of content right from the start.

Now, maybe HarvesteR still intends it to be that way, but currently, as it sits now, it is nothing more than a feature that unlock parts as a reward for grinding science.

> 
> Just having a grid doesn't do that. Have a contract to unlock a node you don't need? Pft, skip it. If anything, I'm not sure the tech tree implements this well enough. I'm not a big plane person so I'll tend to keep the entire string of plane parts unresearched for quite a while until finally I'm just forced to unlock them for some reason for I finally feel like, maybe, I should go back and research them.

If the idea is that you have to research everything whether you like it or not, then you're not talking about a tech tree, you're talking about a tech pyramid, which means that a player arbitrarily unlocks nodes when they get to a certain science amount, and requires total lateral acquisition before vertical advancement is allowed. The fact that you currently skip spaceplane parts means that you are using the tree as the designers intended. ![:wink:](//kerbal-forum-uploads.s3.us-west-2.amazonaws.com/emoticons/default_k_wink.gif)

As for skipping contracts that unlock a node you don't need: well, why not? Why shouldn't a player tailor their game experience the way they want to? Why should a player's game experience be the one that is arbitrarily set (either by statistical analysis or a ridiculous need to cling to 80s gameplay) rather than an organic process of exploration *that can change with every new game?*

And why does it have to be set exclusively to contracts? Why can't contracts make it easier to gain access to a node, or reveal a node earlier? Or parts for that matter? In fact, why can't we have nodes with overlapping/shared parts between them that are accessed at different times or triggered by certain events? What about parts or nodes that are unlocked due to player failures? Or the idiotic idea that the nodes need to be hidden (because players won't just look the tree up on reddit/wiki/wherever)?![:huh:](//kerbal-forum-uploads.s3.us-west-2.amazonaws.com/emoticons/default_k_undecided.gif)

IMHO, KSP is an innovative game: the tech system should be innovative as well.
